Def.Name: Bur Oak
Def.Description: Large tree growing to heights of 50' - 100' tall. Rounded crown with strong, spreading branches. Trunk diameter up to 4'.
Def.Leaves: Alternate, simple, 4" - 12" long, 3" - 6 wide, pinnately lobed; lobes, 5 - 10, center pair cut almost to the midrib, rounded tips; shiny, dark green; yellow or brown in autumn.
Def.Twigs: Yellowish to gray-brown, sometimes hairy, often with corky ridges of wings; buds, red-brown, clustered at twig end.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Acorn, 3/4" - 2" long, deep cup covering top half or more, with hairy margins; mature in autumn.
Def.Bark: Dark gray-brown, furrowed, rugged; becoming deeply furrowed with thick, vertical ridges.
Def.Range: Hardy to zone 3a. Native from southern Canada to Texas and east from the Dakotas and Minnesota to the Alantic Coast.
Def.Remarks: Best of any tree in a fire. Thick bark and deep tap root. Requires lots of space to flurish.
